planet.name: 11 UMi b
planet.description: 11 Ursae Minoris is a star located in the constellation Ursa Minor and also named Pherkard or Pherkad Minor.

planet.name: 14 And b
planet.description: 14 Andromedae is an evolved star in the constellation of Andromeda. It was formerly a white dwarf.

planet.name: 14 Her b
planet.description: The star 14 Herculis is only 59 light years away in the constellation Hercules. However, because it is an orange dwarf star it can not be seen with the naked eye. There is only one confirmed planet in the system, but a dynamical analysis suggests that they might be two planets locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: 16 Cyg B b
planet.description: 16 Cygni ABC is a hierachical triple system. The star is in the Kepler field of view. In an active search for extra-terrestrial intelligence a radio message has been sent to this system on May 24 1999. It will reach the system in 2069.

planet.name: 18 Del b
planet.description: 18 Delphini is a star in the constellation of Delphinus.

planet.name: 1RXS1609 b
planet.description: 1RXS J160929.1-210524 is a 5 million year old pre-main sequence star in the constellation of Scorpius. The observed planet has a large semi-major axis, posing problems for current formation scenarios. Two possibilities are that the planet formed by gravitational instability or migrated outwards.
planet.imagedescription: This image of the host star and the planet was taken with the Gemini North telescope and released in September 2008. Credit: Gemini Observatory.

planet.name: 24 Sex b
planet.description: 14 Sextantis is located in the constellation of Sextans. The two planets in the system are in a 2:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: 24 Sex c
planet.description: 14 Sextantis is located in the constellation of Sextans. The two planets in the system are in a 2:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: 2M1207 b
2MASS J12073346-3932539 b
planet.description: 2M1207 might be the first directly imaged extrasolar planet. However, due to its high mass it might also classify as a brown dwarf.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the brown dwarf 2M1207 and a planetary companion (lower left). It was the first image of an extrasolar planet and has been published 2004. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: 4 Uma b
planet.description: 4 Ursae Majoris is also known as Muscida.

planet.name: 42 Dra b
planet.description: 42 Draconis is a metal poor star.

planet.name: 47 Uma b
planet.description: 47 Ursae Majoris is a solar analog. It hosts at least three planets. The habitable zone could host a terrestrial planet in a stable orbit. Two METI messages called 'Teen Age Message' and 'Cosmic Call 2' have been sent to 47 Ursae Majoris. They will reach the planets in 2047 and 2059.

planet.name: 47 Uma c
planet.description: 47 Ursae Majoris is a solar analog. It hosts at least three planets. The habitable zone could host a terrestrial planet in a stable orbit. Two METI messages called 'Teen Age Message' and 'Cosmic Call 2' have been sent to 47 Ursae Majoris. They will reach the planets in 2047 and 2059.

planet.description: 47 Ursae Majoris is a solar analog. It hosts at least three planets. The habitable zone could host a terrestrial planet in a stable orbit. Two METI messages called 'Teen Age Message' and 'Cosmic Call 2' have been sent to 47 Ursae Majoris. They will reach the planets in 2047 and 2059.

planet.name: 51 Peg b
planet.description: 51 Pegasi is a Sun-like star in the constellation Pegasus. The planet is also called Bellerophon.

planet.name: 55 Cnc b
planet.description: 55 Cancri is a binary system in the constellation Cancer. 55 Cnc b and c are in a near 1:3 resonance. A dynamical analysis shows that the system has to be almost coplanar in order to be stable for the age the system.

planet.name: 55 Cnc c
planet.description: 55 Cancri is a binary system in the constellation Cancer. 55 Cnc b and c are in a near 1:3 resonance. A dynamical analysis shows that the system has to be almost coplanar in order to be stable for the age the system.

planet.name: 55 Cnc d
planet.description: 55 Cancri is a binary system in the constellation Cancer. 55 Cnc b and c are in a near 1:3 resonance. A dynamical analysis shows that the system has to be almost coplanar in order to be stable for the age the system.

planet.name: 55 Cnc e
planet.description: 55 Cancri is a binary system in the constellation Cancer. 55 Cnc b and c are in a near 1:3 resonance. A dynamical analysis shows that the system has to be almost coplanar in order to be stable for the age the system.

planet.name: 55 Cnc f
planet.description: 55 Cancri is a binary system in the constellation Cancer. 55 Cnc b and c are in a near 1:3 resonance. A dynamical analysis shows that the system has to be almost coplanar in order to be stable for the age the system.

planet.name: 6 Lyn b
planet.description: The star 6 Lyncis is a subgiant and 15 times more luminous than our Sun.

planet.name: 7 CMa b
planet.description: This planet is orbiting the star 7 CMa and was discovered by the Pan-Pacific Planet Search (PPPS). It is the first detection from this ongoing survey.

planet.name: 70 Vir b
planet.description: The star 70 Virginis is located in the constellation Virgo and starting to evolve into the subgiant phase. It has a dust disc at 3.4 AU.

planet.name: 81 Cet b
planet.description: The star 81 Ceti is a G-type giant in the constellation of Cetus.

planet.name: 91 Aqr b
planet.description: 91 Aquarii is a triple star system in the constellation Aquarius.

planet.name: AB Pic b
planet.description: AB Pictoris is a star in the constellation of Pictor. Because of its high mass, the companion could be a planet or a brown dwarf.
planet.imagedescription: This is a coronagraphic image of AB Pictoris. A planetary companion is visible on the lower left. It was optained with NACO on the VLT with an occulting mask on top of AB Pictoris. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: Alpha Centauri B b
planet.description: Alpha Centauri is one of the brightest stars in the southern sky (in fact, it is a triple system). European astronomers have discovered a planet with about the mass of the Earth orbiting Alpha Centauri B. It is the nearest exoplanet to Earth and also the lightest exoplanet ever discovered around a Sun-like star. The planet was detected using the HARPS instrument on the 3.6-metre telescope at ESO's La Silla Observatory in Chile.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows the planet orbiting the star Alpha Centauri B, a member of the triple star system that is the closest to Earth. Alpha Centauri B is the most brilliant object in the sky and the other dazzling object is Alpha Centauri A. Our own Sun is visible to the upper right. The tiny signal of the planet was found with the HARPS spectrograph on the 3.6-metre telescope at ESO's La Silla Observatory in Chile.
Credit: ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: BD +48 738 b
planet.description: This planet was found by the Penn State-Torun Planet Search Team (PTPS) using the Hobby-Eberly Telescope.

planet.description: The star BD-103166 is a K-type main sequence star in the constellation Crater. It is three times as metal-rich as our Sun.

planet.name: BD-17 63 b
planet.description: The star BD-1763 is a K-type star in the constellation Cetus. It is five times less luminous than our Sun.

planet.name: BD20 2457 b
planet.description: The star BD+242457 is located in the constellation Leo. Its metallicity is ten times lower compared to our Sun.yy

planet.name: beta Pic b
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the planet Beta Pictoris b. It has been optained with NACO on VLT. The star has been masked out to enable the viewer to see clearly the planet. Credit: ESO.

planet.name: CFBDS 1458 b
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the binary CFBDSIR J1458+1013AB. It was obtained with the Keck II Telescope in Hawaii. This is the coolest brown dwarf (or exoplanet, depending on the precise mass) found yet. Credit: Michael Liu (University of Hawaii).

planet.name: CHXR 73 b
planet.description: The companion CHXR 73 b is just under the threshold for deuterium fusion. Therefor, its status as a planet is uncertain.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the red dwarf CHXR 73 A and its companion CHXR 73 b on the lower right. The image was obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope. Credit: NASA, ESA, and K. Luhman (Pennsylvania State University).

planet.description: The star CoRoT-1 is a sun-like star in the constellation of Monoceros. The planet CoRoT-1b is the first planet discovered by the European space mission CoRoT (COnvection, ROtation and planetary Tansits).

planet.description: CoRoT 7 is a G-type star in the constellation Monoceros. The planet CoRoR 7b was the first rocky planet found. However, due to its high temperature the planet might be covered in lava.

CoRoT-Exo-7 c

planet.description: The star CoRoT 7c is a G-type star in the constellation Monoceros. The planet is not transiting.

planet.name: CT Cha b
planet.description: CT Chamaeleontis is a pre-main sequence T Tauri star. The companion might be a brown dwarf due to its large mass.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the young star CT Cha and a companion (on the right). Due to its large mass it is currently unclear if the companion is a planet or brown dwarf. Credit: Tobias Schmidt (AIU Jena).

planet.name: DH Tau b
planet.imagedescription: This image shows the companion to the star DH Tauri on the lower left. The star itself has been masked to enhance the contrast. Credit: Subaru Telescope, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan.

planet.name: DP Leo b
planet.description: DP Leonis is an eclipsing binary system.

HD 143107 b
HR 5947 b
HIP 78159 b
planet.description: Radial velocity measurements for eps CrB exhibit periodic variation of 417 days with an amplitude of 129 meter per second. The minimum mass for the planetary companion is 6.7 Jupiter masses.

HD 216956 b

planet.description: Formalhaut is one of the brightest stars in the night sky and located in the constellation Piscis Austrinus. It is a young star with a debris disk. In 2008 astronomers reported the discovery of a planet orbiting the star within the debris disk. Two images from the Hubble space telescope showed motion consistent with a Keplerian orbit. The discovery was not confirmed in subsequent images. The planet is therefore listed as controversial.

planet.name: Gliese 1214 b
GJ 1214 b
Gj 1214 b
Gl 1214 b
planet.description: Gliese 1214 is a red dwarf in the constellation Ophiuchus only 40 light years away. The planet was found with a 40cm telescope and commercially available cameras. New observations from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope show that it is a waterworld enshrouded by a thick, steamy atmosphere. GJ1214b represents a new type of planet, like nothing seen in our solar system or any other planetary system currently known.
planet.imagedescription:
This image shows an artist's view of the planet Gliese 1214 b in front of its host star.
Credit: NASA, ESA, and D. Aguilar (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics).

planet.name: Gliese 176 b
GJ 176 b
Gj 176 b
Gl 176 b
planet.description: Gliese 176 is a red dwarf located in the constellation Taurus. It has half the mass of our Sun. The planet consists mainly of rock but probably has a thick gas atmosphere.

planet.description: The star Gliese 170 is located in the constellation Orion. The planet was discovered with the Keck Observatory on Mauna Kea in Hawaii.

GJ 317 b

planet.description: The star Gliese 317 is a red dwarf in the constellation Pyxis. So far only one planet is confirmed. There might be a second planet in the system, locked in a 4:1 mean motion resonance.

planet.name: Gliese 3470 b
LP 424-4
2MASS J07590587+1523294
planet.description: The planet Gliese 3470 b is a transiting Hot Uranus orbiting a nearby M-dwarf. The planet was originally seen in HARPS radial velocity data and then confirmed to be a transiting planet.

planet.name: Gliese 433 b
GJ 433 b
Gj 433 b
Gl 433 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 433 is a red dwarf in the constellation Hydro. The radial velocity data shows an additional signal with a period of 10 years. However, due to a strong correlation with various activity indicators of the star, it is most likely due to a magnetic cycle and not a planet. The cycle is similar to the Sun's 11 year cycle.

planet.name: Gliese 436 b
GJ 436 b
Gj 436 b
Gl 436 b
planet.description: The star Gliese 436 is located in the constellation Leo. Due to tidal forces the planet Gliese 436b is expected to circularise on short timescales. It might be perturbed by an additional planet in the system.

planet.name: Gliese 436 c
GJ 436 c
Gj 436 c
Gl 436 c
UCF-1.01
planet.description: The star Gliese 436 is located in the constellation Leo. While observing the already known planet Gliese 436 b with the Spitzer Space Telescope, astronomers have discovered an additional transiting planet Gliese 436 c. The planet is also known as UCF-1.01. There might be even more planets in the system.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's concept shows what astronomers believe is an alien world just two-thirds the size of Earth. It was identified by NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope. UCF-1.01 might be the nearest world to our solar system that is smaller than our home planet.
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: Gliese 581 b
GJ 581 b
Gj 581 b
Gl 581 b
planet.description: Gliese 581 is a red dwarf in the constellation Libra. It is the 89th closest star to the Solar System. In late 2010, US astronomers annoucent a planet in the habitable zone. This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 c is likely to have a runaway greenhouse effect. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 c is likely to have a runaway greenhouse effect. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

planet.name: Gliese 581 d
GJ 581 d
Gj 581 d
Gl 581 d
planet.description: Gliese 581 is a red dwarf in the constellation Libra. It is the 89th closest star to the Solar System. In late 2010, US astronomers annoucent a planet (Gliese 581f) in the habitable zone. This statement has been challenged by the European HARPS team. Gliese 581 d might be habitable according to a paper by Wordsworth et al. (2011) who studied the system using three dimensional climate simulations. A radio message has been sent to Gliese 581 in 2008 and will reach the star system in 2029.

planet.description: Gliese 581 f is an unconfirmed planet. Its discovery was announced in 2010 by the Lick-Carnegie Exoplanet Survey. However an analysis by the European HARPS team concluded that the system is unlikely to contain a planet with the quoted characteristic.

planet.name: Gliese 581 g
GJ 581 g
Gj 581 g
Gl 581 g
planet.description: Gliese 581 g is an unconfirmed planet. Its discovery was announced in 2010 by the Lick-Carnegie Exoplanet Survey. However an analysis by the European HARPS team concluded that the system is unlikely to contain a planet with the quoted characteristic. The planet attracted a lot of attention because of its location near the middle of the habitable zone.

planet.name: Gliese 667C b
GJ 667C b
planet.description: Gliese 667 C is a member of a triple star system in the constellation Scorpius. The star hosts at least two planets. The outer planet, Gliese 667 Cc, is right in the middle of the habitable zone. It receives only 10 percent less stellar energy than the Earth receives from the Sun.

planet.name: Gliese 667C c
GJ 667C c
planet.description: Gliese 667 C is a member of a triple star system in the constellation Scorpius. According to a study by Delfosse and collaborators from the Joseph Fourier University in Grenoble the planet Gliese 667 Cc is right in the middle of the habitable zone. It receives only 10 percent less stellar energy than the Earth receives from the Sun.

planet.name: Gliese 876 b
GJ 876 b
Gj 876 b
Gl 876 b
planet.description: Gliese 876 is a red dwarf only 15 light years from Earth in the constellation Aquarius. The orbits of the outer three planets are locked in a Laplace reasonance. This resonance is also present in the moons of Jupiter: Io, Europa, Ganymede. This strong dynamical interaction leads to interesting conclusions about the formation history of the system. It is a very strong indication that the planets migrated in the protoplanetary disk to their current position and got locked into mean motion resonances during that process.

2MASS 07350197+1749482

These planets might be inflated because some of the stellar irradiation is somehow transported into the planetary interior. Excess energy could also be injected into the interior by tides if the planet was initially on an eccentric orbit.

planet.description: The star HAT-P-7 is located in the constellation Cygnus and in the field of view of the Kepler spacecraft. Meassurements of the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect suggest that this planet is in a retrograde orbit. Retrograde orbits are difficult to explain with standard disk migration. Planet-planet scattering or the Kozei effect are able to produce retrograde orbits.

planet.name: HD 10180 b
planet.description: HD 10180 is a solar type star in the constellation Hydrus. The planetary system contains at least 7 planets with masses comparable to the ice giants in the solar system. There is even evidence for two more planets, but these are still awaiting confirmation. The planets in this system are in near resonance. The age of the star is 7.3 Gigayears. The planets have been discovered with the HARPS spectrograph at the La Silla Observatory in Chile.

planet.name: HD 128311 b
planet.description: This planetary system is most likely in a 2:1 mean motion resonance. The inner planet orbits the star exactly twice during one orbit of the outer planet. This is a very stable configuration. Mean motion resonances help us to understand the formation of multiplanteray systems. The existense of this resonance is a strong indication that interactions with the protoplanetary disk migrated the planets to their current positions. A detailed analysis of the HD 128311 system shows that there also had to be non-adiabatic effects during the migration phase such as a third planet (Sandor and Kley 2006) or turbulence in the protoplanetary disk (Rein and Papaloizou 2009).

planet.name: HD 209458 b
planet.description: By studying the carbon monoxide gas in the upper atmosphere with great accuracy, astronomers found evidence for a wind, blowing at a speed of 5000 to 10000 km per hour.
planet.imagedescription:
Astronomers have measured a superstorm for the first time in the atmosphere of the planet HD 209458 b. The very high-precision observations of carbon monoxide gas show that it is streaming at enormous speed from the extremely hot day side to the cooler night side of the planet.
This artist's impression shows the Jupiter-like transiting planet around its solar-like host star.
Credit:
ESO/L. Calcada

planet.description: The planetary system HD 37605 hosts at least two planets. The inner planet is on a 55 day orbit with a very high eccentricity of 0.6767. This planet was discovered in 2004. In 2012, another planet on a 2720 day orbit was anounced. In contrast to the inner planet, HD 37605 c is on an almost circular orbit. This leads to interesting speculations on the origin of the planetary system.

planet.description: The star HR 8799 is a young star in the constellation of Pegasus. It hostst a debri disk and at least 3 planets. The objects are near the upper limit for being planets. Objects are classified as brown dwarfs if they are capable of deuterium fusion (above 13 Jupiter masses).

planet.name: KELT-2A b
HIP 29301 b
WDS J06107+3057A b
TYC 2420-00899-1 b
HD 42176 b
BD+30 1138 b
SAO 58830 b
2MASS J06103935+3057258 b
planet.description: This planet is a typical Hot Jupiter. It is the first planet discovered by the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope-North (KELT-North) survey. KELT-2A is the third brightest star with a transiting planet identified by ground-based transit surveys, and the ninth brightest star overall with a transiting planet. The planet might have been put on its orbit by the binary companion KELT-2B via the so-called eccentric Kozai mechanism.

planet.description: KELT-3 b is a moderately inflated transiting hot Jupiter. It is orbiting a late F-type start which is among the 20 brightest known transiting planet host stars. It was discovered by the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope-North (KELT-North) survey.

planet.name: Kepler-10 c
KIC 11904151 c
2MASS J19024305+5014286 c
planet.description: This planet was confirmed using infrared observations from Spitzer. It is highly unlikely (0.002%) that Kepler-10 c is a false positive. The planet is so close to its host star that it can not sustain liquid water on its surface. It is therefore most likely not habitable and a scorched, molten Earth.

planet.name: Kepler-11 g
planet.description: The mass of this planet is an upper limit.

planet.name: Kepler-14 b
KIC 10264660 b
TYC 3546-00413-1 b
2MASS J19105011+4719589 b
KOI-98 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. The host star is in a close visual binary. The object was previously known as KOI-98 (Kepler Object of Interest).

planet.name: Kepler-15 b
2MASS J19444814+4908244 b
KOI-128 b
KIC 11359879 b
planet.description: Kepler-15b is a planet discovered by NASA's Kepler mission and confirmed by the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The density of the planet is high, suggesting an enrichment in heavy elements.

planet.name: Kepler-16 (AB) b
planet.description: Kepler-16 (AB) b is a circum-binary planet. It is orbiting two stars. The visualizations below are therefore not accurate. The masses of the stars are 0.20255 and 0.6897 solar masses. The orbit of the binary stars and the planet are perfectly alligned within half a degree. This suggests that the planet formed in a circumbinary disc.
planet.imagedescription: This image shows an artist's illustration of the Kepler-16 (AB) b exo-planet orbiting two binary stars. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/R. Hurt

planet.name: Kepler-17 b
2MASS J19533486+4748540 b
KOI-203 b
KIC 10619192 b
planet.description: Kepler-17b is a planet on a short orbit around a solar mass star. One year on this planet equals 1.5 days on Earth. Star spots on the host star constrain the eccentricity and obliquity of the planet.

planet.name: Kepler-18 b
GSC 03149-02089 b
KIC 8644288 b
2MASS J19521906+4444467 b
planet.description: The Kepler-18 system is hosting at least three tansiting plantes. It was discovered with the Kepler satellite, and confirmed by a combination of large transit-timing variations, radial-velocity variations, Warm-Spitzer observations, and a statistical analysis of false-positive probabilities.

planet.name: Kepler-19 b
TYC 3134-1549-1 b
GSC 03134-01549 b
KOI-84 b
2MASS J19214099+3751064 b
KIC 2571238 b
planet.description: Sinusoidal transit timing variations have been detected in this system. An additional planet might be present.

planet.name: Kepler-20 b
2MASS J19104752+4220194 b
KOI-70
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 b has a period of only 3.7 days. Because it is about twice as big as the Earth, it is classified as a super-Earth or sub-Neptune. Kepler-20 b's composition is ambiguous. It could be a terrestrial planet with a rocky surface or it could have a significant gas envelope.

planet.name: Kepler-20 c
2MASS J19104752+4220194 c
KOI-070
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 c has a low mean density which means it cannot be composed of rocky and iron material alone but must have a gas envelope.

planet.name: Kepler-20 d
2MASS J19104752+4220194 d
KOI-070
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 d has a low mean density and cannot be composed of rocky and iron material alone. The planet has an equilibtrium temperature of 95C (205F).

planet.name: Kepler-20 e
2MASS J19104752+4220194 e
KOI-070.04
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least five transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 e is most likely a rocky planet made of iron and silicates. It has approximately the size of Venus and is the first discovery of a sub-Earth size planet by the Kepler team. It is not habitable because the planet is on an orbit very close to its host star and the equilibrium temperature is as high as 1000 Kelvin (726C, 1340F).

planet.name: Kepler-20 f
2MASS J19104752+4220194 f
KOI-070.05
planet.description: The Kepler-20 system hosts at least 5 transiting exo-planets. Kepler-20 f is orbiting the star every 20 days and has a size similar to that of Earth. It is too close to the star to be habitable. However, it could have developed a thick water vapour atmosphere.

planet.name: Kepler-21 b
HIP 94112 b
TYC 3120-00963-1 b
HD 179070 b
BD+38 3455 b
SAO 67891 b
2MASS J19092683+3842505 b
KIC 3632418 b
KOI-975 b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. It is orbiting Kepler's brightest host star and is only 1.6 times larger than the Earth.

planet.name: Kepler-22 b
KIC10593626 b
planet.description: The planet Kepler-22b has been discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. It is orbiting the solar type Kepler target star KIC10593626. This puts it in the habitable zone with an equilibrium temperature of minus 11 degrees Celsius (plus 11 degrees Fahrenheit). If the planet has an atmosphere similar to that of Earth then the surface temperature is 22 degrees Celsius (71 degrees Fahrenheit). Kepler-22b is the smallest radius planet known to orbit in the habitable zone of any star other than the Sun.
planet.imagedescription:
This is an artist's conception illustrating the exoplanet Kepler-22b. The planet lies in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star KIC10593626. The habitable zone around a star is usually defined to be the zone in which liquid water, a requirement for life on Earth, could persist.
Scientists do not yet know if the planet has a predominantly rocky, gaseous or liquid composition. It's possible that the world would have clouds in its atmosphere, as depicted here in the artist's interpretation.
Credit: NASA/Ames/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: Kepler-23 b
KOI 168.01
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-23 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis. However, the mass of the planets is not well constrained yet and should be considered an upper limit.

planet.name: Kepler-34(AB) b
KIC 8572936 b
Kepler-34 b
planet.description: Kepler-34(AB) b is a Saturn-sized planet orbiting two Sun-like stars which are in a binary (therefore the name with AB). The Kepler team estimates that approximately 1% of all close binary stars have planets. This yields a galactic population of at least several million.

planet.name: Kepler-35(AB) b
KIC 9837578 b
Kepler-35 b
planet.description: Kepler-35(AB) b is a planet orbiting two sub solar-mass stars which are in a binary (therefore the name with AB). The Kepler team estimates that approximately 1% of all close binary stars have planets. This yields a galactic population of at least several million.
planet.imagedescription:
This is an artists conception of the planet Kepler-35 b orbiting a binary star.
Illustration by Lynette Cook, http://extrasolar.spaceart.org.

planet.name: Kepler-36 b
KOI 277.01
KIC 11401755 b
2MASS 19250004+4913545 b
planet.description: The Kepler-36 system consists of a pair of planets which are twenty times more closely spaced than any adjacent pair of planets in the Solar System. Their densities differ significantly. Kepler-36 b is most likely a super-Earth, whereas Kepler-36 c might resemble Neptune.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's conceptions shows Kepler-36 c as seen from the surface of the neighboring planet Kepler-36 b.
Image credit: Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics/David Aguilar.

KIC 6762829
KOI-1740
2MASS J19071928+4216451
Kepler-38 b
planet.description: Kepler-38(AB) b is a Neptune-sized planet orbiting a binary star (therefore the name with AB). The stellar mass quoted here is the sum of the two stellar components. The planet is not sufficiently massive to alter the orbit of the binary. Therefore one can only place an upper limit on the mass of the planet of 122 Earth masses.

KIC 10020423 b
KOI 3154 b
2MASS J19411149+4655136 b
Kepler-47 b
planet.description: Kepler-47(AB) is a multiplanetary system orbiting a binary star. This is the first system of its kind. One of the binary stars is a Sun-like star (quoted here), the other one is roughly one-third its size. The orbital period of the binary is 7.45 days.
planet.imagedescription:
An artists depiction of the Kepler-47 system.
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/T. Pyle

One of the binary stars is a Sun-like star (quoted here), the other one is roughly one-third its size. The orbital period of the binary is 7.45 days. The outer planet Kepler-47(AB) c is located in the habitable zone where liquid water could exist.

planet.description: This planet was not flagged as a potential planet candidate by the Kepler data pipeline. Citizen scientists discovered the transit simply by looking at many light curves by eye using the online tool at planethunters.org.

planet.name: KOI-13 b
KOI-13.01
planet.description: The exoplanet candidate KOI-13 b was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. It has been independently confirmed by ellipsoidal variations in the lightcurve. The high temperature of the host star and the small semi-major axis make this planet one of the hottest exoplanets known. The equilibrium temperature is 2864K.

planet.name: KOI-196 b
2MASS J19380317+4558539 b
KIC 9410930 b
planet.description: KOI-196 b is transiting its host star and was tagged as a planet candidate by the Kepler spacecraft. Astronomers then used the SOPHIE spectrograph at the Observatoire de Haute-Provence in France to confirm the planet. The day side temperature on the planet is almost 1700 degree Celsius.

planet.name: KOI-200 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: KOI-202 b

planet.name: KOI-206 b

planet.name: KOI-254 b
planet.description: KOI-254 b was originally discovered by the Kepler spacecraft. It has now been confirmed to be a planet by radial velocity measurements, adaptive optics imaging and spectroscopy. The host star is an M-type dwarf star, just over half the size of our own sun. KOI-254 b is the first hot Jupiter that has been found around such a low mass star.

planet.name: KOI-423 b
KIC 9478990 b
planet.description: This planet was confirmed by SOPHIE measurements (Bouchy et al. 2011).

planet.name: KOI-55 b
planet.description: The planet KOI-55 b is orbiting a former red-giant star. It probably survived deep immersion in the red-giant's envelope. When the star ran out of hydrogen after about 10 billion years, it swelled dramatically. Our own sun will also undergo this phase and expand as far as the Earth's orbit. The planet that we see today in the KOI-55 system might just be the dense core of an evaporated giant planet which survived the death of its sun. The planet was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft but is not transiting. It is inferred from brightness pulsations.

planet.name: KOI-730 b
planet.description: The planetary system KOI-730 has been discovered by Kepler. The planet masses have not been confirmed. However, a dynamical study by Fabrycky et al suggests that this system is real.

planet.name: KOI-961 b
KOI-961.01
planet.description: KOI-961 is an M-dwarf with transit signals of at least three short-period planets. The properties of the star are very similar to those of Barnard's star, the fourth closest star to the Sun. All planets in the system are very close to their host star and thought to be rocky. The system is more similar in size to Jupiter and its moons than any other planetary system.

Artist's concept of the planetary system KOI-961 with three planets orbiting an M-dwarf.
Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: LKCA 15 b
planet.description: The young (2 Myr) solar analog LkCa 15 shows evidence for a (proto)planet surrounded by dusty material. The object is located in a known gap in the transitional disk. More planets might be present in this system.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-477L b
MOA 2010-BLG-477L b
planet.description: Densely coverered observations of a high-magnification event led to the discovery of the planet MOA-2010-BLG-477 b. Many different telescopes around the world have been used in this collaborative effort, including a 40cm telescope in Antartica.

planet.name: MOA-2012-BLG-311 b
planet.description: This object was observed in a gravitational mirolensing event. A good mass estimate could not be obtained although the object is most likely of planetary nature. Unfortunately microlensing events are not repeatable and the planet is therefore marked as controversial.

planet.name: MOA-bin-1 b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered in data from the 2006-2007 MOA project by Bennett et al (2012). It is the first planetary event in which the stellar host is only detected through binary microlensing events. Note that the discovery paper has not been published in a peer-reviewed journal yet.

planet.name: NY Vir b
planet.description: The rapidly pulsating eclipsing binary NY Vir has a period of 0.1 days. On a much longer timescale of 7.9 years, the system exhibits small amplitude cyclic variations which are associated with a third body in the system. A recent paper by Qian et al claims that this body is a giant circumbinary planet orbiting NY Vir at a distance of 3.3 astronomical units. There might be another planet in this system with an even longer orbital period, probably more than 15 years.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L b
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L c
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.

planet.name: KIC 4862625 (AB) b
Planet Hunters 1 b
PH-1 b
planet.description: PH 1 b is a circumbinary planet. It is orbiting a double star (only one star is currently shown in the app, update to fix this is coming soon). There is a second pair of stars at approx. 1000 AU. Citizen scientists discovered this planet by looking at many light curves using the online tool at planethunters.org.
planet.imagedescription:
An artist's conception of the planet in a four-star system.
Credit: Image by Haven Giguere/Yale.

planet.name: Pr0201 b
BD+20 2184
2MASS J08414382+2013368
planet.description: This planets is a so-called Hot Jupiters which orbits tightly around its parent stars in the Beehive Cluster, a collection of roughly 1,000 stars that appear to be swarming around a common center. The planet is not habitable but its sky would be starrier than what we see from Earth.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of a planet in the Beehive cluster.
Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

The planet is not habitable but its sky would be starrier than what we see from Earth.

planet.name: PSR 1719-14 b
PSR J1719-1438 b
planet.description: The 5.7ms pulsar PSR J1719-14 shows timing variations on a 2.17 hour timescale. These can be explained with a Jovian planet. However, because of the planet's short distance to the star, its density has to be more then 20 times that of Jupiter. The planet is most likely a remnant of a binary star which avoided complete destruction. The chemical composition, pressure and dimensions of the planet indicate that it is crystallized, or in other words, a very big diamond (Bailes et al 2011).

planet.name: Qatar-2 b
GSC 04974-00112 b
2MASS J13503740-0648145 b
planet.description: Qatar-2b is a transiting hot Jupiter orbiting a K dwarf and was found by the Qatar Exoplanet Survey (QES). The radial velocity data shows evidence for a second companion with a period of about one year and a mass several times that of Jupiter.

planet.name: tau Boo b
planet.description: The planet Tau Bootis b was one of the first exoplanets to be discovered back in 1996. In 2012, astronomers have detected the faint glow that is emitted from the planet, reliably probing the structure of the atmosphere of Tau Bootis b and deducing its mass accurately for the first time.

planet.name: UZ For(ab) d
planet.description: UZ Fornacis is an eclipsing polar binary. High-speed photometry and archival eclipse timing data spanning 27 years suggest the presence of extrasolar planets (Potter et al 2011).

2MASS J04150149-2206591 b
TYC 5889-271-1 b

TYC 7038-834-1 b

planet.name: WTS-1 b
planet.description: The Hot Jupiter WTS-1 b is the first extrasolar planet found by the WFCAM Transit Survey. The observations were made at the 3.8-m United Kingdom Infrared Telescope and the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The planet has one of the largest radius anomalies among the known Hot Jupiters its mass range.
